name: Kepler-292
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-292 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-292 is a star with 0.7250000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.83 times its radius. It is located 3546.07 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-292 is known to have 5 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-292 b

Kepler-292 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.58 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-292.

The mass of Kepler-292 b is 1.88 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-292 b is 1.32 that of Earth. At 1.88 Earth masses, Kepler-292 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-292 c

Kepler-292 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.72 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-292.

The mass of Kepler-292 c is 2.42 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-292 c is 1.47 that of Earth. At 2.42 Earth masses, Kepler-292 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-292 d

Kepler-292 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.06 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-292.

The mass of Kepler-292 d is 6.60 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-292 d is 2.23 that of Earth. At 6.60 Earth masses, Kepler-292 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-292 e

Kepler-292 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 11.98 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-292.

The mass of Kepler-292 e is 10.14 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-292 e is 2.67 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-292 e is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-292 f

Kepler-292 f was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 20.83 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-292.

The mass of Kepler-292 f is 7.51 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-292 f is 2.35 that of Earth. At 7.51 Earth masses, Kepler-292 f is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-292, which contains 5 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
